dosimetry.e: More dose per pulse â†’ more recombination â†’ larger correction.

nucmed.e: Ideal for imaging: long enough for prep and scanning, short enough for low patient dose.

Limited by positron range, photon non-collinearity, and crystal size.

Average dose in a standard phantom for a single rotation. Measured in mGy.

radiobio.e: Î± = single-hit kills (linear), Î² = two-hit kills (quadratic). Foundation of fractionation theory.

Fast-dividing tissues (tumours, skin, mucosa) are less sensitive to fraction size changes.
The biological rationale for fractionation â€” each R favours tumour kill over normal tissue damage.
Ratio of doses needed for same effect in hypoxic vs oxygenated cells.
Hypoxic cells need 2.5-3Ã— more dose. Reoxygenation between fractions helps overcome this.
Compares biological effect of different radiation types relative to a reference (250 kVp X-rays).

Wider separation = better. RT aims to maximise TCP while keeping NTCP acceptably low.
Biologically Effective Dose. Allows comparison of different fractionation schedules.
Unusually low â€” prostate tumours behave like late-responding tissue. Supports hypofractionation.

radprot.e: The overarching principle: minimise dose consistent with practical constraints.
Minimise time, maximise distance (inverse square), interpose shielding.
